questions.text: Indication for this incision: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open rhinoplasty

 

The image shows an incision along the columella and the nostrils, characteristic of an open rhinoplasty approach. In open rhinoplasty, this type of incision allows the surgeon to lift the skin over the nasal dorsum, providing direct visualization of the underlying bony and cartilaginous structures, including the alar cartilages and nasal bones. This approach is used for making precise adjustments to the shape of the external nose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell luc: Caldwell-Luc surgery is a procedure primarily used for accessing the maxillary sinus. It involves making an incision in the gingivobuccal sulcus (inside the mouth) to enter the maxillary sinus through the anterior wall. This approach is not related to nasal dorsum access and does not involve incisions on the external nose.

 

 

Option B. Midfacial degloving: Midfacial degloving is a technique used for the removal of extensive nasopharyngeal tumors, such as juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibromas (JNA). It involves lifting the facial soft tissues, including the nasal mucosa, through incisions made intraorally. This method provides access to the nasal cavity and maxillary sinus but does not involve an incision like the one shown in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incision shown in the image is specific to open rhinoplasty, allowing direct access to the nasal structures for reshaping and reconstructive procedures.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus. What is his GCS score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E2V3M4

 

The GCS score of this patient is E2V3M4

 

  • Opening eves to a painful stimulus - E2
  • Speak inappropriately - V3
  • Withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus - M4

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is an essential tool for assessing the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury.
  • It involves evaluating the eye opening response, verbal response, and motor response, with scores ranging from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake).
  •  Understanding how to correctly assess and calculate the GCS score is crucial for determining the severity of the injury and guiding appropriate medical intervention.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

 

  • Diagnosis based on the given image: Pseudoexfoliation syndrome (PES)
  • PES is an age-related degenerative disorder, commonly seen in women.
  • Characterized by deposition of an amorphous grey dandruff-like material on:
    • Pupillary border
    • Anterior lens surface
    • Posterior surface of iris
    • Zonules
    • Ciliary processes
  • Trabecular blockage by exfoliative material can lead to:
    • Secondary open-angle glaucoma
    • Rarely, angle-closure glaucoma
  • Other ocular symptoms may include:
    • Iris sphincter atrophy
    • Anisocoria
    • Heterochromia
  • Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.

  • Common intraocular foreign bodies:
    • Glass particles or metal chips.
  • Sites of lodgement: 
    • The anterior chamber
    • Lens
    • Posterior chamber
    • Vitreous humour
  • Consequences of lodgement: 
    • Cataract formation
    • Vitreous liquefaction
    • Retinal haemorrhages
    • Tears
    • Organic foreign bodies can cause infection.
    • Iron foreign bodies can cause siderosis.
    • Copper ones can result in chalcosis.
  • An entry wound can be identified with topical fluorescein.
  • MRI is contraindicated in metallic intraocular foreign bodies.

 

Option C.

 

Ocular trauma can be of 2 types:

  1. Closed-globe injury: can vary from simple corneal abrasions to widespread intraocular damage. A corneal abrasion highlighted with fluorescein staining is shown below.
  2. Open-globe injury: includes globe rupture or laceration.

 

 

Option D. Vossius ring is used to describe a ring-shaped pigment dispersal observed on the anterior surface of the lens due to the deposition of brown amorphous pigment granules. It is close to the constricted pupil in diameter. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, creating an impression of the iris on the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of amorphous grey dandruff-like material on various parts of the eye, leading to potential complications like secondary open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A patient present at 10 weeks pregnancy. She asks for medical method of abortion. What will you advise her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mifepristone and misoprostol

 

The Ans. is Mifepristone and misoprostol. Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) using mifepristone and misoprostol is recommended for up to 12 weeks of gestation as per the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines.

 

 While the Government of India allows medical abortion up to 9 weeks, the WHO supports the use of this regimen until 12 weeks, though the likelihood of failure increases slightly as the gestational age advances. Mifepristone is an anti-progestin that primes the uterus, and misoprostol, a prostaglandin, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy. This combination is effective and widely used in the first trimester and can also be employed in the second trimester with adjustments in misoprostol dosing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperosmolar saline: This is an outdated method and primarily used in the second trimester. It is not recommended for first-trimester abortions due to associated risks and inefficacy compared to current medical regimens.

 

Option C. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is primarily used to induce labor in the second or third trimester. It is not effective or commonly used for first-trimester medical abortions due to its different mechanism of action and limited efficacy in early gestation.

 

Option D. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone is a prostaglandin used primarily for cervical ripening and labor induction in the third trimester. It is not suitable for first-trimester medical abortion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a medical abortion at 10 weeks, the recommended regimen is mifepristone followed by misoprostol, as it is effective and safe up to 12 weeks of gestation according to WHO guidelines.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with headaches for 6 months. She has been taking analgesics regularly. The headache recently increased in severity for 3 days but was reduced on stopping the analgesic. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Medication overuse headache

 

Medication overuse headache (MOH) occurs in individuals who frequently use headache medications. The patient in this case has been experiencing headaches for six months and has been regularly using analgesics. The key indicator of MOH is the worsening of headaches with continued use of medication and improvement upon stopping the medication. This aligns with the patient's experience of increased headache severity for three days, which reduced once the analgesics were stopped.

 

MOH develops as a result of the brain becoming sensitized to the medication, leading to a rebound effect. This is a well-recognized phenomenon where the headache itself is caused by the frequent use of headache relief medication, leading to a cycle of medication use and headache.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tension headache: Tension headaches are typically relieved by analgesics, not worsened. These headaches are often characterized by a feeling of a tight band around the head and can be managed effectively with over-the-counter pain relief medications. 

 

  • Acute Treatment: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or paracetamol are used to relieve pain.
  • Chronic Treatment: Tricyclic antidepressants, such as amitriptyline, are employed to manage chronic symptoms and reduce the recurrence of headaches.

 

Option C. Chronic migraine: Chronic migraines are managed with both acute treatments for individual attacks and preventive treatments to reduce the frequency and severity of the headaches. While chronic migraines can be debilitating, they generally improve with proper prophylaxis and do not worsen with the use of analgesics.

 

  • Treatment options include propranolol, topiramate, valproate, and monoclonal antibodies against CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide), such as erenumab. These are used to reduce the frequency and severity of migraine attacks.

 

Option D. Cluster headache: Cluster headaches are severe, unilateral headaches that are treated with high-flow oxygen and subcutaneous sumatriptan during acute attacks. Preventive treatments include medications like verapamil. Analgesics are not typically the first-line treatment for cluster headaches and their use does not generally lead to worsening of the condition.

 

  • Acute Treatment: High-flow 100% oxygen inhalation or subcutaneous sumatriptan injections are recommended to alleviate the intense pain of acute cluster headache attacks.
  • Chronic Treatment: Verapamil is used for long-term management to prevent the frequency and intensity of cluster headache episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medication overuse headache is characterized by the worsening of headaches due to frequent use of headache medications, and improvement upon cessation of the medication. This phenomenon highlights the importance of managing headache disorders with appropriate treatments and avoiding overuse of analgesics.

questions.text: During an ocular examination, the ophthalmologist observes the presence of the shifting fluid sign in the patient. This finding suggests that the patient might have which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exudative RD

 

  • Shifting fluid is a hallmark feature of serous or exudative retinal detachment.
  • In serous retinal detachment, there is subretinal accumulation of serous fluid mostly due to breakdown in blood-retinal barrier.
  • Fluid shifts to the dependent portion when head position is altered.
  • Serous retinal detachment has a smooth convex configuration and lacks a retinal tear or preretinal traction.
  • Rhegmatogenous RD presents with tobacco dust in anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells, and retinal breaks.
  • Traction RD has a concave configuration, absent breaks, and severely reduced retinal mobility.
  • Shifting fluid is absent in traction RD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traction RD: Tractional retinal detachment is caused by fibrovascular proliferation and contraction of epiretinal membranes, leading to mechanical traction on the retina. It has a concave configuration and lacks shifting fluid due to the tethering of the retina by fibrous tissue. Retinal mobility is severely reduced, and retinal breaks are usually absent.

 

Option C. Rhegmatogenous RD: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment occurs due to a retinal tear or hole that allows vitreous fluid to enter the subretinal space. It presents with signs such as tobacco dust (Shafer's sign) in the anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood, inflammatory cells, and visible retinal breaks. Shifting fluid is not a characteristic feature of rhegmatogenous RD.

 

Option D. Retinal Dialysis: Retinal dialysis is a type of retinal tear that typically occurs at the ora serrata, where the retina is particularly thin and prone to tearing. It is most often seen in younger patients or those who have experienced trauma. Shifting fluid is not a specific feature of retinal dialysis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of these is the definition of effective CPR?

 

  1. Respiratory rate: 20 - 24 breaths per minute.
  2. Chest compressions: 100-120/min.
  3. Allow complete chest recoil.
  4. 5-6 cm depression.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2, 3 and 4

 

Components of High-Quality CPR:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Effective CPR includes the following components:

 

  • Chest compressions: 100-120/min. This ensures that the heart is pumping enough blood to maintain circulation during cardiac arrest.
  • Allow complete chest recoil. Allowing the chest to fully recoil between compressions ensures that the heart fills adequately with blood between each compression, which is crucial for effective circulation.
  • 5-6 cm depression. The depth of chest compressions should be between 5-6 cm (2-2.4 inches) for adults. This depth is essential to create enough pressure to maintain circulation.

 

Other Option:

 

  1. Respiratory rate: 20-24 breaths per minute. This is not correct for effective CPR. The recommended respiratory rate during CPR is about 10-12 breaths per minute when an advanced airway is in place. Higher respiratory rates can lead to hyperventilation, which can be detrimental.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Effective CPR is characterized by chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute, allowing complete chest recoil, and compressing the chest to a depth of 5-6 cm.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2529-2534

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has arrived with a gradual swelling on the left side of his face persisting for two weeks. He had a prior incident of trauma involving wood, which occurred two months ago. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasal passages and paranasal sinuses reveals a mass within the subcutaneous tissue of the left cheek. Examination of a tissue sample obtained via biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, with positive staining observed using PAS and GMS methods. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis. GMS positive confirms this.

It is fungal infection which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs. 

Other Options:

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: This is a term historically used to describe aggressive midline facial granulomatous diseases, often linked to conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). It does not fit the biopsy findings or clinical scenario described here.

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Although the biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, the positive PAS and GMS staining suggests a fungal etiology, which is characteristic of Phycomycosis.

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: This is associated with IgG4-related disease, which presents with different clinical and histopathological findings, not typically involving PAS and GMS positive fungal elements.

Educational Objective:

Phycomycosis should be considered in patients with a history of trauma, swelling, and positive fungal stains (PAS and GMS), particularly if they have underlying conditions like diabetes or immunosuppression.

questions.text: A patient with gastrointestinal symptoms and neurological symptoms underwent a blood examination whose peripheral smear image is provided here. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abetalipoproteinemia

 

The image provided shows red blood cells with irregular, spiky projections, known as acanthocytes.

 

Acanthocytes (also known as a spur cell) are characterized by asymmetrical and irregular projections, unlike echinocytes, which have evenly spaced projections.

 

Acanthocytes are strongly associated with abetalipoproteinemia, a rare disorder caused by a defect in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein, leading to impaired fat absorption and deficiency of lipoproteins like LDL and VLDL. Echinocytes are typically observed in conditions like uremia or burn injuries.

 

 

Abetalipoproteinemia presents with a combination of gastrointestinal symptoms (such as malabsorption) and neurological symptoms (like ataxia and neuropathy) due to deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins, especially vitamin E. The presence of acanthocytes in the blood smear is a hallmark of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uremia: Uremia can lead to the formation of burr cells (echinocytes), which have regularly spaced projections. However, these projections are symmetrical and differ from the irregular projections seen in acanthocytes.

 

Option B. Burns: Burn injuries can also lead to the formation of burr cells (echinocytes) due to alterations in red cell membrane structure caused by thermal damage. The symmetrical projections of echinocytes are distinct from the asymmetrical projections of acanthocytes.

 

Option D. Hereditary spherocytosis: This condition is characterized by spherical red blood cells (spherocytes) due to a defect in the red cell membrane proteins. It does not present with spiky projections like acanthocytes, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acanthocytes, or spur cells, are red blood cells with irregular, spiky projections associated with abetalipoproteinemia, a disorder characterized by fat malabsorption, vitamin deficiencies, and neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of depressed mood, anhedonia, insomnia, and feelings of hopelessness. The patient has a history of a similar episode with full recovery approximately five years ago. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent Depressive Disorder

 

Recurrent Depressive Disorder (RDD) is diagnosed when a patient has experienced two or more depressive episodes, with each episode separated by at least two months of remission. In this case, the patient presents with symptoms of a current depressive episode and reports having experienced a similar episode five years ago, with full recovery in between. The presence of more than one depressive episode aligns with the criteria for Recurrent Depressive Disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Major Depressive Disorder: This would be considered if the patient was experiencing their first depressive episode. Since the patient has had a previous depressive episode, the diagnosis is Recurrent Depressive Disorder rather than a single Major Depressive Disorder.

 

Option C. Dysthymia: Also known as Persistent Depressive Disorder, dysthymia is characterized by chronic, mild depressive symptoms that last for at least two years. The patient's symptoms are more severe, consistent with major depressive episodes rather than mild chronic symptoms, which rules out dysthymia.

 

Option D. Cyclothymia: Cyclothymia involves periods of hypomanic symptoms and mild depressive (bipolar) symptoms over at least two years, but the symptoms do not meet the criteria for a full hypomanic episode or a full depressive episode. The patient's presentation does not include any hypomanic symptoms, making cyclothymia an incorrect diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent Depressive Disorder is diagnosed when a patient experiences two or more major depressive episodes, separated by periods of remission

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a male patient in his early twenties who presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of abdominal pain and obstipation, and reports blunt injury to the abdomen 3 days prior? The provided X-ray image may provide clues to the diagnosis: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • The given radiograph in the erect position indicates air under the diaphragm, which is a typical finding in cases of hollow viscus perforation.
  • A history of trauma, accompanied by symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation, supports the diagnosis of a perforation of the alimentary tract.

 

A perforation of a hollow organ (like the intestines or stomach) can lead to air and contents of the organ leaking into the abdominal cavity. It can be a result of trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemothorax: This condition is characterized by the accumulation of blood within the pleural cavity, often due to trauma. The patient's symptoms are abdominal in nature and not respiratory, making this an unlikely diagnosis. Hemothorax would be evident on a chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: This is the presence of air in the pleural cavity, often due to trauma or a spontaneous event, leading to lung collapse. Similar to hemothorax, this condition is related to the respiratory system and would not be the cause of abdominal pain or obstipation.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: This condition involves a blockage that prevents the contents of the intestines from passing normally through the digestive tract. However, no free air should be seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation can cause acute bacterial peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum that can be localized or generalized.
  • Clinical features of peritonitis include abdominal pain that worsens with movement, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, and guarding on palpation. Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.
  • An erect abdominal radiograph that shows free gas under the diaphragm.
  • Management of peritonitis involves general care of the patient in terms of nutritional support and pain relief. Laparotomy and surgical treatment of the cause is usually necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Human genome project?  (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It took 2 years to discover

 

  • Explanation: Option D is false. The Human Genome Project did not take only 2 years to complete. It was a long-term endeavor that spanned over a decade. The official launch of the project was in 1990, and a working draft of the human genome was announced in 2000. The project was completed in 2003.
  • Relevance: This statement is false, and the actual timeline of the Human Genome Project demonstrates that it was a multi-year, collaborative effort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collaboration of Many Countries:

 

  • Explanation: The Human Genome Project was indeed a collaborative effort involving many countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Japan, and others. It aimed to map and sequence the entire human genome.
  • Relevance: This statement is true and reflects the international nature of the project.

 

Option B. 20,000 Total Genes Were Identified :

 

  • Explanation: During the Human Genome Project, it was estimated that there are approximately 20,000-25,000 protein-coding genes in the human genome. This estimate is relatively accurate, considering the complexity of the human genome.
  • Relevance: This statement is true and reflects one of the significant achievements of the HGP.

 

Option C. It Uses Modern Sequencing Techniques:

 

Explanation: 

 

  • The project initially started with Sanger sequencing, which was state-of-the-art at the time.
  • Towards the end and afterward, next-generation sequencing (NGS) evolved, further enhancing genome studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Human genome project started in 1990 and completed with sequence of Y chromosome this year in 2022. So, it took > 2 decades. This was a collaborative project spread across many labs in different countries across world. Approximately 22000 genes were identified in entire Human genome using High throughput Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) techniques.

 

Reference: Harper’s 30th ed/pg- 98

questions.text: A patient following head injury with altered consciousness, vomiting, and GCS of 10/15 undergoes CT scan as shown. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompression

 

The patient presents with signs of an acute epidural hematoma (EDH), as evidenced by the biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion on the CT scan, along with a deteriorating Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10/15. An epidural hematoma is a neurosurgical emergency, especially when accompanied by neuro deterioration, as in this case. The immediate next step is decompression, which involves relieving the pressure on the brain by surgically removing the hematoma. This procedure can be done through a burr hole or craniotomy and is crucial to prevent further brain injury or death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Mannitol: Although IV mannitol is used to reduce intracranial pressure, it is not the definitive treatment for an acute EDH with neuro deterioration. Mannitol may be used temporarily to manage intracranial pressure, but it does not address the underlying cause of the pressure, which is the hematoma.

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This approach is inappropriate in this scenario due to the immediate threat posed by the hematoma. Delaying treatment could lead to irreversible brain damage or death.

 

Option D. Anticoagulation: Administering anticoagulation would exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient’s condition. It is contraindicated in the setting of an active intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidural hematoma with neuro deterioration is a neurosurgical emergency that requires immediate decompression to prevent further brain injury and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Captopril

 

Explanation

 

Captopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, and ACE inhibitors are known to be absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy. They can cause fetal toxicity, particularly in the second and third trimesters, leading to complications such as renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, pulmonary hypoplasia, and even fetal death. Therefore, ACE inhibitors should be avoided in pregnant women.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Paracetamol: Generally considered safe for use during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Cefixime: A cephalosporin antibiotic, also considered safe during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Azithromycin: An antibiotic that is commonly used and considered safe during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

ACE inhibitors, such as captopril, are absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of fetal toxicity and complications.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation is experiencing symptoms of fever, acute abdominal pain, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Red degeneration of fibroid

 

RED DEGENERATION OF FIBROID

 

  • Occurs in a large fibroid mainly during second half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • The cause is not known but is probably due to thrombosis and infarction
  • The typical presentation is severe abdominal pain especially in the 2nd trimester of pregnancy.
  • Treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration
  • TLC is raised but the etiology is not infective
  • Surgery is NOT done for red degeneration
  • Can also happen in the puerperium and in women on combined OCPS

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine torsion: Uterine torsion can lead to birth obstruction, abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, shock, and urinary and intestinal symptoms.

 

Option B. Infection of fibroid: Infection of fibroid can cause blood-stained purulent discharge

 

Option D. Preterm labor: Preterm labor doesn’t relate with fever, raised TLC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Red degeneration of fibroid, which typically occurs in the second half of pregnancy or puerperium, presents with severe abdominal pain, fever, and a slight increase in white blood cell count. It is caused by thrombosis and infarction of the fibroid, and treatment is symptomatic with analgesics and hydration. Surgery is not performed for red degeneration.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foot drop

 

Explanation:

 

The most common postpartum nerve injury is an injury to the peroneal nerve, which results in foot drop. This type of injury often occurs during deliveries where the lithotomy position is used for an extended period. The lithotomy position can cause prolonged pressure on the peroneal nerve, which is located near the fibular head, leading to nerve damage.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Peroneal nerve injury: The peroneal nerve is susceptible to compression, especially when the legs are positioned in stirrups for prolonged periods, as is common in the lithotomy position during childbirth.
  • Foot drop: This condition is characterized by an inability to dorsiflex the foot, leading to a dragging foot while walking.
  • Symptoms: Patients may present with weakness in lifting the front part of the foot and toes, a high-stepping gait to prevent the foot from dragging, and numbness or tingling over the top of the foot and the outer part of the upper leg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial palsy: This is not commonly associated with postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Option B. Wrist drop: This condition results from a radial nerve injury and is not a common presentation of postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Option D. Claw hand: This is associated with ulnar nerve injury and is also not a common presentation of postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common postpartum nerve injury is peroneal nerve injury, leading to foot drop, often associated with the lithotomy position used during childbirth.

questions.text:
Organize the given steps of Karyotyping into the accurate sequence. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Collect cells by peripheral vein using a heparin syringe
  2. Culture in phytohaemoagglutinin
  3. Incubation at 37°C for 3 days
  4. Harvest with colchicine
  5. Routine staining with Giemsa
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

 

Karyotyping is a process that allows for the visualization of chromosomes in a cell, usually to diagnose genetic diseases, identify chromosomal abnormalities, or analyze chromosomal structures. The accurate sequence for conducting karyotyping involves several key steps, each critical to ensuring accurate results.

 

  1. Collect cells by peripheral vein using a heparin syringe: Blood is typically drawn from a peripheral vein using a syringe containing heparin, an anticoagulant that prevents blood from clotting, thereby preserving the cells for further processing.
  2. Culture in phytohaemoagglutinin: The collected cells, which contain lymphocytes, are then cultured in a medium containing phytohaemoagglutinin (PHA), a mitogen that stimulates lymphocytes to enter mitosis. This step is crucial because chromosomes are most easily visualized and analyzed during mitosis.
  3. Incubation at 37°C for 3 days: The cell culture is incubated at 37 degrees Celsius for approximately 3 days to allow the cells to grow and divide, ensuring a sufficient number of cells reach the metaphase stage of mitosis.
  4. Harvest with colchicine: Colchicine is added to the culture to arrest cells in metaphase by disrupting the mitotic spindle formation. This ensures that a large number of cells are caught in metaphase, where chromosomes are most condensed and visible for karyotyping.
  5. Routine staining with Giemsa: After harvesting, the cells are fixed, dropped onto a slide, and stained with Giemsa stain. This stain provides a distinct banding pattern on the chromosomes, which helps in identifying and analyzing the structure and number of chromosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The accurate sequence for conducting Karyotyping is outlined below:

questions.text: A dye factory worker with a history of benzidine exposure undergoes cystoscopy. What is the appropriate management? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoscopy with removal of tumor

 

The patient, a dye factory worker with a history of benzidine exposure, undergoes cystoscopy which reveals a bladder growth. Benzidine exposure is a known risk factor for bladder cancer. The appropriate initial management for a bladder tumor identified on cystoscopy is to perform a cystoscopic removal of the tumor, also known as transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT). This procedure allows for both the resection of the tumor and a biopsy to determine the stage and grade of the cancer.

 

  • If the tumor is non-muscle invasive (T1), intravesical BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guerin) therapy is administered to reduce the risk of recurrence.
  • If the tumor is muscle-invasive (T2 or worse), more radical treatment such as radical cystectomy (removal of the bladder) may be necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV BCG: This is incorrect as initial treatment. BCG is used as an adjuvant therapy after TURBT for non-muscle invasive bladder cancer.

 

Option C. TURP (Transurethral Resection of the Prostate): This is incorrect as TURP is a procedure used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), not bladder tumors.

 

Option D. Radical cystectomy: This is not the initial step. It is considered if the tumor is muscle-invasive or in cases of high-risk non-muscle invasive bladder cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of a bladder tumor seen on cystoscopy is to perform a cystoscopic removal (TURBT) to both resect the tumor and obtain a biopsy for staging and grading.

choices.text: He has consumed alcohol and is under the influence of alcohol
He has consumed alcohol but is not under its influence

questions.text: In an examination for drunkenness, a person smells of alcohol and his conjunctiva appear red. During his motor examination, it is observed that he can walk in a straight line and can talk normally. Which of the following statements is true?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. He has consumed alcohol but is not under its influence

 

The presented situation depicts an individual emitting the scent of alcohol, yet their motor coordination remains unaffected, and there is no slurring of speech. This suggests that they might have consumed alcohol previously, but they are not currently under its influence.

 

If the individual were unable to walk in a straight line or displayed slurred speech, they would be considered under the influence of alcohol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. He has consumed alcohol: This statement is true, but it does not address the influence of alcohol on the person's abilities.

 

Option B. He has consumed alcohol and is under the influence of alcohol: This statement would be true if there were signs of impaired motor coordination or slurred speech, which are not present in this case.

 

Option D. He has not consumed alcohol: This statement is false as the smell of alcohol and red conjunctiva indicate consumption of alcohol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood-Alcohol Concentration and Symptoms:

questions.text: Patient died and relatives said he had a tattoo, but it was not visible on autopsy. Which is the best location to check for the evidence of tattoo?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymph node

 

Explanation

 

When a tattoo is not visible on autopsy, it may be due to fading or complete disappearance. In such cases, the best way to check for evidence of the tattoo is to look for the tattoo ink in the nearby lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spleen: Incorrect because the spleen is not typically involved in draining tattoo ink.

 

Option B. Artery: Incorrect as arteries do not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option D. Liver: Incorrect because the liver is not a primary site for tattoo ink deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a tattoo is not visible on autopsy, checking the nearby lymph nodes for the presence of tattoo ink is the best approach to find evidence of the tattoo.

 

Key points to understand about checking for evidence of tattoos:

questions.text: A patient present with an X-ray showing cardiomegaly, along with symptoms of hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, and "floppy baby" syndrome. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pompe's disease


Pompe's disease, also known as Type II glycogen storage disease, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (also known as alpha-glucosidase). This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen in the lysosomes. Without this enzyme, glycogen accumulates within the lysosomes, leading to lysosomal storage disease. The clinical features of Pompe's disease include cardiomegaly, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, macroglossia, and the characteristic "floppy baby" syndrome due to severe muscle weakness. The disease primarily affects the heart and skeletal muscles, often leading to heart failure as seen in the presented X-ray with cardiomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ebstein anomaly: This is a congenital heart defect involving the tricuspid valve but does not present with hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, or the "floppy baby" syndrome seen in Pompe's disease. Ebstein anomaly primarily affects the heart, causing cyanosis and heart failure but lacks the systemic metabolic features of Pompe's.

 

Option C. Transposition of great arteries: This is another congenital heart defect characterized by the abnormal arrangement of the heart's major arteries. While it presents with severe cardiopulmonary symptoms such as cyanosis and heart failure, it does not cause hypotonia, macroglossia, or hepatomegaly, distinguishing it from Pompe's disease.

 

Option D.  Von Gierke's disease: Von Gierke's disease (Type I glycogen storage disease) affects liver metabolism, leading to severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, renomegaly, and metabolic derangements such as lactic acidosis and hyperuricemia. However, it does not involve cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, or "floppy baby" syndrome, making it an incorrect diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Pompe's disease is characterized by the combination of cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and macroglossia, often presenting as "floppy baby" syndrome due to lysosomal storage of glycogen.

choices.text: It decreases glucose utilization by neoplastic cells
It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication
It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production
It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer cells immortal

questions.text: Why do neoplastic cells utilize Warburg metabolism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication

 

Warburg metabolism is used by neoplastic cells to generate metabolic intermediates required for cell growth and multiplication.

 

Even when there is plenty of oxygen available, cancer cells shift their glucose metabolism away from the oxygen-hungry but efficient mitochondria and towards glycolysis. This phenomenon is known as the Warburg effect, and it is also referred to as aerobic glycolysis.

 

This metabolic change is so common in tumors that some consider it the eighth cancer hallmark.

 

Even though the latter produces more ATP, cancer cells prefer glycolysis (2 ATP) to mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (36 ATP) for glucose metabolism. It's because pure oxidative phosphorylation generates a lot of ATP while also converting glucose to CO2 and H2O, leaving no carbon moieties to use as building blocks for lipids or proteins.

 

For this reason, rapidly growing cells, by undergoing glycolysis, produce carbon moieties that are needed for growth and cellular maintenance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It decreases glucose utilization by neoplastic cells: Incorrect. The Warburg effect actually increases glucose uptake and utilization by cancer cells to meet their high metabolic demands.

 

Option C. It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production: Incorrect. Glycolysis produces less ATP compared to oxidative phosphorylation. The advantage of the Warburg effect lies in providing metabolic intermediates, not in ATP production.

 

Option D. It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer cells immortal: Incorrect. While cancer cells do evade apoptosis and become immortal, this is not the direct reason they utilize the Warburg effect. The Warburg effect primarily supports cell growth and multiplication through the generation of biosynthetic precursors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neoplastic cells utilize the Warburg metabolism to generate metabolic intermediates necessary for cell growth and multiplication. Despite being less efficient in ATP production, glycolysis provides carbon moieties needed for biosynthesis of nucleotides, amino acids, and lipids, supporting rapid proliferation and cellular maintenance.

questions.text: Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyometra

 

Explanation:

 

Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) involves infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract, which can include the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries. PID can result from sexually transmitted infections and, if left untreated, can lead to several serious complications.

 

Complications of long-standing pelvic inflammation include:

 

  1. Infertility: Due to damage to the fallopian tubes and the resulting adhesions, which can block the passage of eggs from the ovaries to the uterus.
  2. Ectopic pregnancy: Scarring of the fallopian tubes can cause a fertilized egg to implant outside the uterus, most commonly in the tubes.
  3. Pyometra: Accumulation of pus within the uterine cavity, often due to obstruction of the cervical canal combined with chronic infection.
  4. Dyspareunia: Pain during sexual intercourse, often due to adhesions and chronic pelvic pain.
  5. Chronic pelvic pain: Persistent pain in the lower abdomen, which can be severe and debilitating.
  6. Frozen pelvis: Severe adhesions can cause the pelvic organs to become fixed in place, leading to significant pain and dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine polyposis: Uterine polyposis involves the development of benign polyps within the endometrial cavity and is not typically a direct result of PID.

 

Option C. Pseudocyesis: Pseudocyesis, or false pregnancy, is a psychological condition where a woman believes she is pregnant and may exhibit pregnancy symptoms, but is not related to PID.

 

Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia: Endometrial hyperplasia refers to the thickening of the endometrial lining due to excess estrogen stimulation and is not a direct consequence of PID.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) can lead to serious complications such as infertility, ectopic pregnancy, chronic pelvic pain, and pyometra.

 

Ref: Page no 155, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following bands will increase in serum electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 2 globulin

 

 

  • In Nephrotic syndrome, there is a marked increase in alpha 2 globulin levels on serum electrophoresis. This is due to the liver increasing production of some proteins as a compensatory response to heavy proteinuria, especially proteins like alpha 2 macroglobulin, which are too large to be lost through the glomerulus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gamma globulin: Typically decreased or normal in Nephrotic syndrome due to the loss of smaller immunoglobulins in the urine.

 

Option C. Beta globulin: Generally shows little change in Nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D. Albumin: Markedly decreased in Nephrotic syndrome due to loss in the urine, which is a hallmark of the disease and responsible for the characteristic edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Nephrotic syndrome, Alpha 2 globulin increases on serum electrophoresis as a response to heavy proteinuria, while albumin significantly decreases leading to symptoms such as severe swelling and fluid accumulation in the body.

questions.text: Which biopsy technique is used to diagnose Marjolin ulcer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wedge biopsy

 

Wedge biopsy involves the removal of a small, wedge-shaped piece of tissue from the border of an ulcer. This technique is particularly useful in diagnosing Marjolin ulcers because it is the site where squamous cell carcinomas have maximum proliferation, leading to “everted edge”. Marjolin ulcers often develop in areas of previously injured or scarred skin, and a wedge biopsy can provide a representative sample for histopathological examination to confirm the presence of malignancy.


Other Options:

 

Option B. Excision biopsy: Excision biopsy is the technique of choice for a cervical lymph node pathology, in which the entire lymph node is surgically removed for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Core needle biopsy: Core needle biopsy is preferred for sampling soft tissue sarcomas, in which a small sample of tissue is removed using a large bore needle for examination.

 

Option D. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC): USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the technique of choice for a solitary thyroid nodule, in which a small amount of thyroid tissue is aspirated using a thin needle and examined under a microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A wedge biopsy is the preferred and commonly used biopsy technique to diagnose Marjolin ulcers because it allows for the examination of tissue from the ulceration site.

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the embryological basis for the formation of an omphalocele? ( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Physiological hernia failing to go back

 

  • Omphalocele is characterized by the herniation of abdominal viscera through an enlarged umbilical ring.
  • Amnion protects the viscera, which may include the liver, small and large intestines, stomach, spleen, or gallbladder.
  • The defect is caused by the bowel's failure to return to the body cavity after its physiological herniation between the sixth and tenth weeks.

 

 

Omphalocele is associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive length of the intestine: During early embryonic development, the intestines do grow at a rapid pace, leading to temporary herniation of the midgut into the umbilical cord around the 6th week. This is called physiological midgut herniation. The intestines then rotate and usually return into the abdominal cavity by the 10th week. It's not the excessive length of the intestine itself that causes omphalocele; rather, it's the failure of the intestines (and sometimes other organs) to return to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option C. Herniation of liver: While the liver can indeed be one of the organs present in an omphalocele, its herniation is not the primary cause of omphalocele. Instead, it is a consequence of the failure of the physiological hernia to return to the abdominal cavity. In larger omphaloceles, the liver is more commonly seen as part of the herniated content.

 

Option D. Herniation of umbilicus: This option is not precise. The umbilicus itself is not what herniates in omphalocele. Instead, it's through the region of the umbilicus that the intestines and possibly other organs herniate out into the umbilical cord during development. If they fail to return to the abdomen, an omphalocele forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is primarily caused by the failure of the physiological hernia of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity during fetal development, not merely by the excessive length of the intestine or specific organ herniation.

questions.text: Which of the following factors can decrease iron absorption? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tea

 

Tea, especially black tea, contains compounds called tannins. Tannins can bind to iron, making it harder for the body to absorb. Therefore, drinking tea, especially with meals, can decrease the absorption of iron.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin C: Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, actually enhances iron absorption, especially non-heme iron (the form of iron found in plant-based foods). It does this by converting iron into a form that is more easily absorbed by the body.

 

Option C. Sprouts: Sprouts, like other plant-based foods, contain phytates (phytic acid), which can bind to minerals like iron and inhibit their absorption. However, the process of sprouting reduces the phytate content, which may actually improve the availability of iron.

 

Option D. Gastric Acid: Gastric acid is crucial for iron absorption as it helps convert iron into its ferrous (Fe2+) form, which is more easily absorbed. Reduced gastric acid can lead to decreased iron absorption, as seen in conditions like atrophic gastritis or with the use of certain medications (like proton pump inhibitors).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tea, particularly due to its tannin content, is known to decrease iron absorption. The other options, Vitamin C and gastric acid, typically aid in iron absorption, while sprouts, although containing phytates, have reduced phytate levels due to the sprouting process and are not the primary dietary concern for iron absorption inhibition

questions.text: At 6 weeks of life, a child developed a fever after DPT vaccination. And now child is 10 weeks due for vaccination. What should be done next? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give DPT Vaccination

 

  • Fever following a DPT vaccination does not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. The child should receive the next scheduled DPT vaccination unless there are specific contraindications or severe adverse reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give DT: Giving only DT (Diphtheria and Tetanus) without the pertussis component may not be ideal for overall protection against these diseases. It's important to provide the complete vaccination schedule, including DPT, unless contraindications exist.

 

Option C. Don’t give DPT: This may not be the best course of action. Fever following the initial DPT vaccination is not an absolute contraindication to subsequent doses. The child should continue the vaccination schedule unless there are specific contraindications.

 

Option D. Don’t give any vaccination: This is not the recommended approach. Missing or delaying vaccinations may leave the child susceptible to vaccine-preventable diseases. It's important to adhere to the recommended vaccination schedule whenever possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the approach to managing adverse events following immunization. Recognize that mild reactions, such as fever after a vaccine, do not necessarily contraindicate subsequent doses. Adherence to the recommended vaccination schedule is crucial for providing timely and effective protection against vaccine-preventable diseases

questions.text: Septal perforation caused due to surgery of: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SMR (Submucous Resection)

  

Septal perforation is more commonly associated with SMR (Submucous Resection) than with septoplasty. In SMR, the deviated part of the septum, which includes both the bony and cartilaginous components, is removed. This removal can lead to the loss of structural support from the cartilage or bone. If there is any tear in the mucosal flaps that cover the septum, it may fail to heal properly due to the absence of underlying support, leading to a septal perforation.

 

During SMR, the absence of this central support structure means that even a minor mucosal tear can result in a perforation because the mucosal flaps on either side of the septum may fuse incorrectly, creating a hole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery): FESS is a procedure focused on the sinuses and not the septum itself, thus it does not typically result in septal perforation. This surgery involves the removal of sinus tissue and does not interfere with the septal structure.

 

Option C. Septoplasty: In septoplasty, the septum is straightened by removing or reshaping the cartilage and bone but importantly, the removed parts are replaced back between the mucosal flaps. This restoration of structure reduces the likelihood of perforations because the mucosal layers are supported by the replaced bone or cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septal perforation is a recognized complication of SMR due to the complete removal of septal cartilage and bone without replacement, which can lead to mucosal tears and eventual perforation if the layers do not heal correctly.

choices.text: Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost
Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth
PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery
Causes include retained placenta and atony

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH)? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start colloids initially, 4 times the blood lost

 

The false statement regarding post-partum hemorrhage (PPH) is option A. The standard practice for managing PPH is to start intravenous isotonic crystalloids rather than colloids. Colloids are generally reserved for specific situations and are not the initial choice for fluid resuscitation in PPH. The correct approach involves using crystalloids to replace lost blood volume. The recommendation is not to administer colloids at a volume four times the amount of blood lost.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth: This statement is true. Primary or early postpartum hemorrhage refers to blood loss occurring within the first 24 hours after delivery.

 

Option C. PPH is loss of > 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery: This statement is true. Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as a blood loss greater than 500 ml following a vaginal delivery and more than 1000 ml following a cesarean section.

 

Option D. Causes include retained placenta and atony: This statement is true. Common causes of postpartum hemorrhage include uterine atony (failure of the uterus to contract) and retained placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management of post-partum hemorrhage should involve intravenous isotonic crystalloids, not colloids.

 

Ref: Page 1894, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient who is a known case of ovarian cancer presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from the chair, combing hair etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dermatomyositis

 

The most probable diagnosis is dermatomyositis. The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash which is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis. The clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with a rash in elderly female, with a history of internal malignancy, is also suggestive of dermatomyositis

 

The following list includes several dermatomyositis symptoms:

 

  • Heliotrope rash around eyelids with a lilac hue.
  • Gottron's papules are violaceous, erythematous papules that can appear over the elbow, knee, dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.
  • Shawl sign or V-sign: Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution)
  • Nail fold changes with periungual erythema with visible dilated capillary loops in the proximal nail fold
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual labourer
  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Screening:  Approximately 20 to 40% of patients have an underlying malignancy (eg, lung, ovarian, breast) and hence screening should be done at the time of diagnosis.

 

Diagnosis:  Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Gottron's papule, heliotrope rash, and shawl sign are associated with anti-Mi2 antibodies.

 

Mechanics hand, Myositis, and ILD (Interstitial Lung Disease) are associated with anti-histidyl tRNA synthetase (anti-Jo-1) antibodies.

 

Prognosis: The presence of dysphagia points to a poorer prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • Features: SLE is an autoimmune disorder characterized by a malar "butterfly" rash, arthritis, and a variety of systemic symptoms. It can affect multiple organs, including the skin, kidneys, and nervous system.
  • Why it doesn't match the clinical vignette given in the MCQ: While muscle pain and inflammation can be a part of SLE, the described presentation with a clear muscle weakness pattern, especially in the context of ovarian cancer, is more suggestive of dermatomyositis.

 

Option C. Systemic sclerosis:

 

  • Features: Systemic sclerosis (or scleroderma) primarily affects the skin, leading to thickening and hardening. It can also cause problems in blood vessels, the digestive tract, and other internal organs.
  • Why it doesn't match the clinical vignette given in the MCQ: While systemic sclerosis can affect various organs and can cause muscle weakness indirectly due to skin tightening, the described presentation is more specific to dermatomyositis.

 

Option D. Cushing syndrome:

 

  • Features: Cushing syndrome is caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. Symptoms include weight gain, purple striae on the skin, facial puffiness, and thinning of the skin.

 

 

Cushing syndrome: Striae seen

 

  • Why it doesn't match the clinical vignette given in the MCQ: While muscle weakness can be a symptom of Cushing syndrome, the absence of other hallmark features and the association with ovarian cancer make dermatomyositis a more likely diagnosis in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermatomyositis is diagnosed by the presence of heliotrope rash, Gottron's papules, and proximal muscle weakness, and consider its association with underlying malignancies in adult patients.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Page no 53.5, 53.6 and 53.8, 56.12-15

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition page no 2914

choices.text: It can be done with the opinion of 2 doctors
It cannot be done if there is a fetal Anomaly
It requires the opinion of a medical board

questions.text: A patient presents at 22 weeks for an MTP due to failure of contraception. Which of the following is correct? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It cannot be done

 

As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Amendment Act of 2021, the upper limit for termination due to failure of contraception is 20 weeks.

 

The Act extends the permissible gestational age for termination to 24 weeks, but only in specific cases, including:

 

Fetal anomalies

 

Pregnancies resulting from rape or sexual assault

 

Maternal health risks

 

Certain socio-economic conditions (e.g., a woman becoming a widow or getting divorced after conception)

 

In this case, the patient requests MTP at 22 weeks due to failure of contraception, which is not a legally permissible indication beyond 20 weeks.

 

MTP beyond 20 weeks is only allowed for fetal anomalies and other specific conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can be done with the opinion of 2 doctors: Incorrect because MTP beyond 20 weeks for failure of contraception is not allowed, regardless of the number of doctors.

 

Option B. It cannot be done if there is a fetal anomaly: Incorrect because MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in the presence of substantial fetal anomalies, with a board’s approval.

 

Option C. It requires the opinion of a medical board: Incorrect because a medical board is only required for MTP beyond 24 weeks for fetal anomalies or rare medical conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP for failure of contraception is only allowed up to 20 weeks.

 

MTP between 20-24 weeks is permitted for specific cases such as fetal anomalies, maternal health risks, and pregnancies due to sexual assault.

 

Beyond 24 weeks, termination requires the approval of a medical board for severe fetal anomalies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. What associated complication is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scleromalacia perforans

 

  • Scleromalacia perforans is a complication of rheumatoid arthritis shown in the image.
  • It is a type of necrotizing scleritis without inflammation. Typically occurs in elderly females with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is characterized by the development of yellowish patch of melting sclera. The sclera melts due to obliteration of blood supply.
  • Episclera and conjunctiva often completely separate from the surrounding normal sclera.
  • Sequestrum of sclera becomes dead white in colour.
  • Eventually, sequestrum absorbs leaving behind a large punched-out area of thin sclera through which the uveal tissue shines. Spontaneous perforation is extremely rare.
  • Clinical features include pain, photophobia, and lacrimation. The affected eye appears red.
  • Medical management includes steroids and immunosuppressants.
  • In severe cases, surgical treatment by scleral patch graft may be done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ﻿﻿﻿Ciliary staphyloma:

  • It is used to describe the bulge of an area of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body.
  • Common causes include scleritis, developmental glaucoma, and end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma.
  • Another cause includes thinning of the sclera, secondary to perforating injury.

 

 

Option C. Coloboma:

  • It is a congenital anomaly, that develops due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft.
  • It is characterized by poorly developed or deficient uveal tissue. The lens, choroid, and retina may also be involved.
  • The image below shows coloboma of the right eyelid.

 

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

  • It is usually seen in elderly patients.
  • If it involves the conjunctiva, it appears as a mass near the limbus. It can be pigmented or non-pigmented.
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary body, and eyelids can also develop the tumour.
  • The image below shows malignant melanoma of the conjunctiva.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleromalacia perforans is a severe ocular complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis characterized by a melting patch of sclera with exposure of underlying uveal tissue, typically managed with steroids, immunosuppressants, and potentially surgical intervention.

questions.text: Which vaccine is not recommended to be given before splenectomy in a 5-year-old child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Typhoid vaccine

 

The typhoid vaccine is typically not recommended before splenectomy in a child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism. Typhoid vaccination may lead to a transient decrease in platelet count, which can exacerbate the existing hypersplenism and increase the risk of bleeding. Therefore, it is often deferred until after splenectomy when the risk of post-vaccination thrombocytopenia is reduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal vaccine: The pneumococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia (absence of the spleen) or hyposplenism (reduced spleen function) because they are at an increased risk of severe infections, including those caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the pneumococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenza B vaccine: The Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccine is recommended as part of routine childhood immunization and does not have specific contraindications related to hereditary spherocytosis or splenectomy.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: The meningococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia or hyposplenism, as they are at an increased risk of meningococcal infections. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the meningococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typhoid vaccine is often deferred in children with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism before splenectomy due to the risk of transiently reduced platelet count, which can be problematic in the presence of hypersplenism. Other vaccines, such as the pneumococcal, Haemophilus influenzae B, and meningococcal vaccines, may be administered based on routine immunization recommendations and the individual's spleen status.

questions.text: Binding site of miRNA on mRNA?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3’ UTR

 

  • This is the correct option.
  • miRNA binds to the 3' UTR of mRNA, leading to translational repression or mRNA degradation, thereby regulating gene expression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5’ UTR (Untranslated Region):

  • This region is not typically the binding site for miRNA on mRNA.
  • miRNA primarily binds to the 3' UTR of mRNA to regulate gene expression.

 

Option C. Gene Promoter:

  • Gene promoters are regions involved in transcription initiation, not the binding sites for miRNA.

 

Option D.  Gene Body:

  • miRNA primarily targets the 3' UTR of mRNA, not the gene body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The binding site of miRNA on mRNA is typically the 3’ UTR (Untranslated Region), where miRNA can regulate gene expression by binding and influencing mRNA stability or translation.

 

Ref - Lehninger 6th e/p 1081

questions.text: Identify the airway which can be used to maintain FiO2 of 0.24 to 0.60. (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Venturi Mask

 

Venturi mask can be used to maintain FiO2 of 0.24 to 0.60.

 

A Venturi mask is an oxygen delivery device that provides a fixed concentration of oxygen to patients by mixing oxygen with room air based on the Venturi effect. It is commonly used for patients requiring controlled oxygen therapy, such as those with COPD.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venturi mask can be used to maintain FiO2 of 0.24 to 0.60.

questions.text: Under categorization of triage, the immediately life-threatening injuries would be classified as under the color-coded category: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Red

 

The triage system is used in disaster management to categorize victims based on the severity of their condition and the likelihood of survival. Immediate life-threatening injuries, where a person could die or develop severe complications if no intervention is made within 0 to 6 hours, are classified under the Red category. This category is designated for emergent cases that require immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: This category is for urgent cases where intervention is needed within 6 to 24 hours, such as resuscitation or limb/life-saving surgery. Although these injuries are serious, they are not as immediately life-threatening as those in the Red category.

 

Option C. Green: This category is for non-urgent cases involving minor injuries like fractures, bruises, or lacerations. Patients in this category are ambulatory and can wait for treatment.

 

Option D. Black: This category is for patients who are either deceased or moribund (about to die). It represents the least priority in triage, as these patients have little to no chance of survival.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage Tagging system

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the picture given below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

The structure marked "A" is the levator ani muscle which is the component of pelvic diaphragm.

 

Other structures marked in the above image are:

 

B: External anal sphincter

C: Obturator internus

D: Perianal fascia

 

Pelvic diaphragm -

 

The pelvic diaphragm is the muscular part of the pelvic floor. It connects to the pelvic wall on both sides, between the greater and lesser sciatic foramen. The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the levator ani and coccyges muscles, which define the lower limit of the true pelvis.

 

 

Pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, and puborectalis combine to form Levator ani. The muscles in both sexes blend together posterior to the vagina and around the anus. The form in which the anococcygeal body attaches to the coccyx posterior to the anal aperture.

 

Urogenital hiatus is present anteriorly separating the muscles. This allows the urethra and vagina to pass through. Levator ani reinforces the external anal sphincter. In women, it functions as the vaginal sphincter.

 

The coccyges muscles are triangular in shape and form the posterior part of the pelvic diaphragm, one on each side. The apices are attached to the ischial spine tips. The bases connect to the coccyx and sacrum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphincter Ani Externus (External Anal Sphincter): This is a circular muscle that surrounds the anus. It's located below the level of the levator ani. It is innervated by the pudendal nerve, allowing for voluntary control over defecation.

 

Option C. Obturator Muscle: This term often refers to two muscles - obturator externus and obturator internus. They are situated on either side of the obturator membrane in the pelvis. Obturator Externus: Obturator nerve and Obturator Internus: Nerve to obturator internus (a branch of the sacral plexus).

 

Option D. Perianal Fascia: The perianal fascia is not a muscle but is the connective tissue located in the perianal region, around the anus. It's part of the deeper layers of the skin in this region.  It's associated with various potential spaces that can become sites of abscess formation if there's an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The levator ani is the principal muscle of the pelvic floor and is composed of three parts: the puborectalis, the pubococcygeus, and the iliococcygeus. It is primarily innervated by the pudendal nerve and the S4 nerve root.

questions.text: The type of synovial joint at the 1st carpo-metacarpal joint is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Saddle joint

 

The 1st carpo-metacarpal (CMC) joint, located at the base of the thumb, is a saddle joint. This type of synovial joint allows for a greater range of motion than other joint types, enabling movements such as flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and opposition of the thumb. The saddle-shaped articulating surfaces of the trapezium and the first metacarpal bone allow for this unique range of motion, making it particularly important for thumb function. This joint is also commonly affected in conditions like osteoarthritis due to the high degree of mobility and the stresses placed on it during daily activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ball and socket joint: Ball and socket joints, such as the shoulder or hip joint, allow for movement in multiple axes and planes. This type of joint is not found at the 1st CMC joint.

 

Option B. Ellipsoid joint: Ellipsoid joints, like the wrist joint, allow for movement in two planes but do not offer the same rotational capability as a saddle joint. This type of joint is not characteristic of the 1st CMC joint.

 

Option C. Hinge joint: Hinge joints, such as the elbow or knee, allow movement primarily in one plane (flexion and extension). The 1st CMC joint, with its multi-directional movement, is not a hinge joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 1st carpo-metacarpal joint is a saddle joint, enabling the thumb's unique range of motion and playing a crucial role in hand dexterity.

questions.text: MTP after 24 weeks is done for? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetal anomaly

 

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks is permitted only in cases of substantial fetal anomalies. The MTP Act amendment of 2021 allows for this provision to ensure that pregnancies with severe and life-threatening fetal conditions can be terminated to prevent undue suffering for both the fetus and the parents.

 

The process involves a medical board, which is established at the district level or within medical colleges. This board typically includes a radiologist, a gynecologist, a pediatrician, and any relevant subspecialists depending on the nature of the anomaly. The board evaluates whether the fetal anomaly is substantial enough to warrant termination of the pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Minor: Termination for minors is allowed up to 24 weeks but not beyond.

 

Option C. Rape: Termination for pregnancies resulting from rape is allowed up to 24 weeks but not beyond.

 

Option D. Contraceptive failure: Termination due to contraceptive failure is allowed up to 20 weeks and, in some cases, up to 24 weeks but not beyond.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP beyond 24 weeks is allowed only for substantial fetal anomalies, as determined by a medical board, to ensure the safety and well-being of the mother and to address severe fetal conditions.

 

Indication for MTP -
